TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. Minister, is it true that your department briefed you late last year on their assessment of the Austudy actual means test? Is it true that your department identified numerous defects in the actual means test regime and concluded that it did not stand up to scrutiny and would require substantial revision? Did you pass on your department's concerns to your colleague Senator Vanstone? If so, when? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have had briefings at different times about means testing. After all, my department I think would quite reasonably be able to lay claim to being specialists in the technicalities of means testings. When I became the Minister for Social Security I was very concerned that the previous administration had not been able effectively to deal with people with substantial means who were accessing social security entitlements. I understood very early on that there was in DEETYA a means test which was trying to deal with this, to stamp out people who, in most people's judgments, would not have been entitled to but were receiving Austudy. So I was very interested to learn about it. In fact, at that stage I did get a briefing about how the Austudy actual means test was working.

ANSWER.PARA: My department has also been doing work on means testing people with substantial means, particularly people with private companies, trusts and such like. That work is proceeding. I have not recently had any detail about it, but I do know that that work is being made available across portfolios as the technical people are talking to each other.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you did not actually answer the second part of the question. Is it true that your department identified numerous defects in the actual means test regime and concluded that it would not stand up to scrutiny? You did say you had received a briefing. Was that the content of the briefing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was at least a year ago that I had that briefing. From memory, I would not have described it in exactly those terms, but they did express some concerns about the actual means test which the previous government had introduced. They felt, while we were all committed to this common cause of eliminating the access of well‐to‐do people to taxpayer‐funded benefits, that there may well be improvements that could be made to the actual means test; therefore they were setting off down a route of trying to improve our ability in social security. I could not comment on the specifics of that because I do not recall what was briefed to me all that time ago.

—My question is addressed to Senator Parer as Minister for Resources and Energy and as a former prominent member of the mining industry. I ask: now that the Century Zinc negotiations under the Native Title Act have failed, with some of the 12 native title groups failing to reach agreement, what has been the effect on exploration and mining of the Wik decision and the failed Century Zinc negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I thank Senator Boswell for that question; it is a very important one. The miners as well as the pastoralists have been misled on this issue—and many other issues—by the previous Labor government when it assured them that pastoral leases extinguish native title. This is yet another Labor mess which we inherited which must be addressed as a matter of urgency.

ANSWER.PARA: The collapse of the negotiations over Century Zinc—against the wishes of the majority of the local Aboriginal community, the company and the state and Commonwealth governments—highlights again the failings of the Native Title Act. Yesterday a number of senators, including myself, were visited by representatives of the Waanyi and Mingginda people, the majority in the Carpentaria area, who requested legislation to correct a situation where a few dissidents could effectively veto a project to the detriment of the majority of their people. They told me that should ATSIC call a vote on the issue there would be a 90 per cent acceptance of that project.

The Century Zinc project offers 3,200 real and indirect jobs in the construction phase and an estimated 4,150 jobs when it goes into production in a region of Australia where there are very few job opportunities—let alone the $600 million per year contribution to the other Labor legacy of a massive foreign debt. The Waanyi and Mingginda people understand the opportunities which this project will provide for them and, more importantly, their children—jobs training, better community services, and opportunities to deliver their own business enterprises. It offers the opportunity for financial independence and escape from the welfare net.

That is why the collapse of the Century Zinc negotiations is a disgrace. It represents an enormous loss in not just time and money but in the hopes and aspirations of all those involved. If every other project in Australia is to be a repeat of Century, the country will grind to a halt. As Senator Boswell implies, it sends an ominous message to investors in our mining and pastoral industries.

Thousands of exploration and mining titles are now under a cloud. Those issued post‐1993 are particularly vulnerable and billions of dollars of investment are at risk. Unless the Wik decision and the unworkability of the Native Title Act are addressed quickly, major adverse effects for Australia will be felt, but not for about four or five years when exploration programs finish and are not replaced and when new mines fail to come on stream to replace worked out deposits. Probably equally important is the fact that we are now seeing a large degree of downstream processing, which is something that I think most people in Australia have been looking for for many years—and that will also stagger.

BREAK.PARA: When the Prime Minister met the Waanyi and Mingginda representatives he assured them that the government is now even more determined to press on with its native title amendments and that their suggestions would be taken on board in determining the outcome. The Prime Minister also said that he hoped the Labor Party, the Democrats and other parties in the Senate would listen carefully to the concerns of those Aboriginal people and support the government's fair and reasonable amendments before the Senate. This is a message which should be heeded by those opposite.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. After 13 years of Labor government many indigenous Australians were left to live in appalling conditions with very few resources to enable them to improve their situation. Will Senator Herron outline how the new coalition government has a commitment to economic independence for indigenous Australians and will he give examples of where Aboriginal people are successfully running businesses and providing employment and training for indigenous Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator O'Chee for his question. This government was elected to office in March this year—
—Last year.

—Last year, and we found that the area of Aboriginal Affairs was an absolute disgrace. We celebrate one year of this government this year and we are looking forward to those celebrations because of the change that we have wrought in many areas of policy. Many indigenous people have been trapped in a poverty cycle from which they have no power to free themselves. This government has set a new direction in Aboriginal affairs and the hallmark of the new era will be economic independence and self‐empowerment.

ANSWER.PARA: Indigenous Australians want to work to provide jobs and training for their children. I had the pleasure, with Senator Parer, of meeting the Waanyi and Mingginda people yesterday. They emphasised they want the changes, too. They want this so their people and their children can have jobs. Senator Kernot is trying to interject. I ask her, `What have you done in the time you have been here?' You have done nothing to help them, either.

Since being appointed Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in March last year, Senator Kernot, I have visited more than 50 communities around Australia—and I will continue to do so—in remote, urban and semi‐urban areas. The strong message coming through is that in digenous Australians do not want to be forever dependent on government handouts, which is what the previous government did; it kept them dependent because it thought it could control their votes. I see that Gary Gray—do you remember Gary Gray?—said:
If we had on more occasions, as a government, said that we were sorry and acknowledged where we got things wrong, then the result in March of last year would have been very different.

We see the Hindmarsh Island bridge decision that you, Senator Kernot, and the Labor Party are perpetuating. Madam President, they have not learnt anything out of the Hindmarsh Island bridge fiasco—and they have not said they were sorry. They should listen to Gary Gray who said that if on more occasions then they had said they were sorry they might be out of the debacle they are in now—but they are going to continue that.

Aboriginal people want to foster a work ethic in their young people; they want their young people to have the self‐esteem that goes with having a job. Indigenous Australians are the only Australians who voluntarily work for the dole through the community development employment projects. Over the past few months I have highlighted many examples of Aboriginal enterprises that have recently been established in providing employment and generating income.

There is the community at Warburton and the people of Badu Island in the Torres Strait who are cultivating and selling pearls, and growing and exporting lobsters to Japan. One of the most outstanding, and one that deserves some publicity, is the Jawoyn Association based in Katherine in the Northern Territory. Last month I had the privilege of flying to Katherine with my colleague Senator Parer for the launch of the Jawoyn Association five‐year plan. The plan focuses on economic independence and providing a future for the Jawoyn people. The Jawoyn Association is held up as a model for all Australians, particularly indigenous Australians, of what can be achieved through hard work—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hard work!

—You over the other side wouldn't know what that meant—hard work, perseverance, determination and a commitment to securing the future for the next generation. All you have left for indigenous people is the legacy of government dependence. They are proud people; they want to break away from government dependence. That is the legacy that you on the other side left them. The Jawoyn Association five‐year plan has included as one of its objectives creating a future where their people can break away from that welfare dependency. Already the Jawoyn Association has had outstanding success in negotiating a number of key mining agreements for the benefit of the community.(Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Herron, could you elaborate on the successes of the Jawoyn people, particularly in relation to the mining negotiations which you mentioned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator O'Chee for his supplementary question. My colleague Senator Parer is knowledgeable about this. The Jawoyn people were the first Aboriginal members of the Minerals Council of the Northern Territory. The Jawoyn Association's Manyallaluk Tours Company at Eva Valley was awarded the brolga award for heritage tourism and took out the Australian Tourism Industry Association's national award in the same category. The list of achievements goes on and on. I know that you, Senator O'Chee, as a North Queenslander and as a Queensland senator are aware of the things that are occurring in Queensland as well. I would like to congratulate the Jawoyn Association and hold them up as a model of economic independence. They are proudly creating a very positive future for the next generation and others will follow their example.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Minister, have you read and analysed the ACOSS commission research which shows that all households, irrespective of their incomes, are losers from the 1996-97 budget and low income households with incomes between $15,000 and $20,000 are very big losers? Do you agree with the conclusions of this research? Can you guarantee that the poor, the needy and the elderly in our community will not be hit again in your government's next round of budget cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to the ACOSS ACTU sponsored study, Senator. I was disappointed that it was in some way selective of the evidence that it used. The situation was that the incidents which might have happened to a range of families were, I understand, all deemed to have occurred to one family. If one family had a reduction in one area they were also deemed to have had a reduction in this, that and the other area, so that you had multiple effects from the budget on one family. The ACOSS ACTU study then put them together.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not had a formal detailed briefing on this, but the brief advice I have had from the department when it first came out was that some of the assumptions were very questionable. I therefore said I would like a much more detailed response on that. I have not received that yet. I think something like $38 was mentioned as being the disadvantage. It was so wrong to say that there would be implications for every family from a whole range of measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you say it is wrong when you have not had a briefing yet?
—Order! Senator Bolkus!

—Senator Bolkus does not want to hear the answer, Madam President, but I presume Senator Gibbs does because she asked the question. It would be hard for her to hear with the rabbiting on that is going on in front of her. This is a serious matter.

BREAK.PARA: I am very concerned that ACOSS and the ACTU would put out a study which is not more closely aligned to the reality for Australia families. It is quite clear that where one family may have experienced a negative impact as a result of some item in the budget they have also had benefits from the budget. You cannot simply take an average and say all families are doing this, that or the other. The ACTU and ACOSS have also had a hang-up about the implications—

TALK.START.PARA: —A hang‐up?

—Yes, they have a hang‐up about the implications on child‐care costs as a result of the removal of the operational subsidy clearly because they are the advocates of the union concerned not the advocates of the parents. The reality is that the claims which were being made to frighten parents from last August onwards have been proved to be not based on fact. It is that sort of rabblerousing to which the Labor Party, the ACTU and ACOSS have all lent themselves to the harm of Australian families, and I deplore that.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you keep referring to one family. Has your department actually analysed the research? Will you table that analysis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to the answer. I said that I have asked for a detailed analysis. Nevertheless, the original response I got was that there were some very questionable assumptions. The report has stacked the number of incidents resulting from the budget decisions that may have occurred on one family. I have asked for a detailed response. I have not got a detailed response yet. I have told you already that I have asked for it. I have told you what the initial response was. What more would you like, Senator?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Is it true that a telecommunications road show is currently touring Australia to discuss the new national code, the post‐1997 regime and electromagnetic radiation? Is it true that this road show is saying that the biological effects of electromagnetic radiation do not present a risk to human health? Is it true that the road show is falsely claiming that the CSIRO holds the view that there are no health effects from electromagnetic radiation? Why is this road show being funded from the $4.5 million set aside for research?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct that there are a series of briefing sessions being conducted by the department in relation to a number of matters of particular community concern—certainly the revised telecommunications national code, which only lasts through until 1 July, and the regime thereafter, and, of course, public health issues. It ought to be perfectly clear that we are, as a government, very concerned to ensure that no-one is exposed to any level of radiation that might be in any shape or form considered to be dangerous. That is why we announced a $4.5 million program over five years to ensure that adequate research continues to be done on this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no shortage of research that has been done. All of that research to date very much indicates that there is no basis for community concern. The most recent is from the Australasian Faculty of Occupational Medicine, which acknowledges that there is considerable uncertainty in the mind of the public. I might say this is due very significantly to people like Senator Allison who continue to ignore the facts and try to play to very emotive and quite often irrational concerns that people have on this issue. The faculty says:

In the opinion of the faculty, at this stage it is not possible to quantify any relationships between radio frequency exposure and subsequent human health effects. AFOM strongly supports the need for further independent quality research. The proposal that this research be coordinated by the National Health and Medical Research Council is supported.
The thing that concerns me most about this whole debate is a press release that Senator Allison put out a couple of weeks ago in which she purported—

TALK.START.PARA: —We saw this coming!

—We knew this was coming, did we? We are embarrassed about it, no doubt. So you ought to be. You said there are a couple of hundred research reports that your office has discovered—and I know you have been obsessed with this issue for quite a while because you see it as having considerable populous potential. You went on to say that none of these reports indicate any significant level of concern but, put together, the weight of evidence suggests that there is a serious problem. That is a paraphrase, but that is essentially the logic. I have never heard such a preposterous attempt to beat up an issue, to beat something out of nothing. That mob over there are not bad at it, but that really takes the cake.

ANSWER.PARA: If ever there was an obvious and demonstrable flaw in a line of argument, it has to be that—that if a lot of independent research projects all amount to saying that there is a one per cent problem and you add them together and you have a hundred of them, then you have a 100 per cent problem. It is just ludicrous. I am not surprised that Senator Allison has waited until now because she has obviously been hoping that that press release will disappear into the vapour. I can assure you that it will continue to get a run as far as I am concerned because it simply indicates that you are not serious about the issue.

Once again, you sit there and giggle and laugh as though somehow this is an issue that ought to be treated with amusement. It is not. It is very serious. The government takes it seriously. We are prepared to continue to fund research, and we want to ensure that the research is based on sensible scientific analysis, not on the sort of populous nonsense that you continue to propagate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister why have you sent officers from your department, from Austel and the Australian Radiation Laboratories to mislead Australians and why are they reassuring people when not one dollar of the $4.5 million has so far been spent on research? I note your answer to the question about the need for independent research and I ask: why is this road show travelling around Australia when that research has not been done?
—I know the Democrats have difficulty in communications and quite clearly—
—Oh!

—You obviously have decided to boycott the telephone. It seems you only communicate by fax these days. I notice for once that one your number is not laughing. I notice that Senator Despoja—or `Destroyer' as she would rather been known, no doubt, in terms of the leadership aspirations she has—does not think it is amusing at all. The fact is we take the view that direct communications—

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. My point of order is one of relevance. The minister is making no attempt to answer the question. I listened for as long as I possibly could and have taken notes, but it is quite clear he has no intention of answering the substance of the question. I would ask you to direct the minister to answer the question he has been asked.
—Order! The minister should be addressing the question put to him by the senator.

—I certainly am, Madam President. Senator Woodley will just have to try harder. The fact is we are very interested in the method of communication. We do not think contacting people by fax is good enough. That is why the department is travelling around Australia and is talking directly to those people who have concerns. If you would rather us simply sit here and send out faxes, maybe we could ask Senator Kernot to help us in that regard. We think it is better to do it at an official level and make sure that we do not get the level of distortion we have seen today. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, is it true that you told the Sydney Morning Herald last week in relation to your department's options paper on cross media ownership that, `You won't get much from the discussion paper I've seen. It's pretty tired stuff'? Have you raised your concerns about the paper with your depart ment and what steps have you taken to revitalise its apparent flagging analytical capacity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see that report and, as will not surprise honourable senators, it is quite inaccurate.
—Did you issue a writ against Anne Davies? She interviewed you personally.
—I hope you read that profile.
—I read the quote.
—You did. Good. I am sorry she did not give you a mention.
—So you are issuing a writ?
—The only one who ought to be suing is Henry Ergas, not me. When is that submission coming, Senator Schacht, by the way?

ANSWER.PARA: Madam President, I was in grave danger of forgetting what the question was, but it has come back to me. The fact is that that report was inaccurate. To the extent that I did comment on the submissions rather than on the views emanating from the department, I think it is fair to say that a number of the submissions—which are on the public record and, indeed, the Internet—are ones that essentially regurgitate fixed positions. In other words, it would come as no surprise to find that people are reflecting their own commercial interests in the arguments they advance in relation to cross media and it is not always the case that the public interest is foremost in their minds. That is not a criticism; it is simply a reflection of commercial reality.

It certainly was not any view on my part that the department had put forward tired views, but simply that the views that had been expressed in a number of those submissions could be regarded as being in that category. That, of course, simply means that, at the end of the day, one has to make judgements about where the national interest lies.

We all know the origin of the cross‐media rules. They were discreet enough not to refer to that, but they know as well as we do that these rules were conceived in malice. They were simply designed by Keating to punish the Fairfax group and the Herald and Weekly Times; they were not, in any shape or form, designed to improve public policy in this important area. We do think it is important to take account of new technological developments, particularly on-line services, and to look at developments around the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anne Davies got it wrong.
—I do not know why you think I should be suing Anne Davies.
—You reckon she got it wrong.
—I am simply saying to you on that specific point, if the article is suggesting that that was the department's view, that was the view—
—That was the quote used specifically. Have you corrected her?
—I am saying to you, that was the view of the submitters. Right?
—Senator Alston, you should be answering Senator Evans's question and not engaging with Senator Schacht across the chamber.

—That is true, Madam President, and I apologise for that. Senator Evans, I am sure, would have studied that article very carefully and he would understand that the point that was being made was that some of the views were tired. I am simply saying to you it was not my intention to indicate that the department's views were tired, but rather that the views expressed by some of the people who made submissions were tired. But at the end of the day it is a fairly trivial distinction in any event, and I could not really see why that would have much bearing on the ultimate outcome, and if you are patient, then we will get to that in due course.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator, I see you have taken the stock defence of blaming the journalist. The key point was you seemed to be unhappy with the submission, and now you are saying you are unhappy with the submissions put in response to the department's submission. In the same interview you are quoted as saying, `My thoughts are still here,' pointing to your head. Is that also inaccurate, or did you mean to say that your views were quite different from the department's? Or was it that there was no way you were going to share them with anybody? Or were you in fact saying that you were incapable of expressing them? When do you propose to share your thoughts, and what use are they to anybody until you do so? It is all very well to criticise everyone else's submissions, but what are you saying about the issue?

—What I am saying about the issue will become apparent in due course. Much and all as I have great respect for Anne Davies, I was not about to give her the scoop of the century by telling her what the government's views might have been on an informal basis.
—The wisdom of Richard Alston! What a scoop. The scoop of the century!

—We have just had Senator Evans suggesting that I would be incapable of doing it. I am glad you now concede the point that at least I could have been capable of giving Anne Davies that sort of information. The fact is I chose not to. I was deliberately refraining from sharing my thoughts with her at this stage because it is a matter for the government itself to take those decisions. It is not simply a matter of me indicating at this stage what view I take or, indeed, what view any other individual takes. This will be a collective decision of government. We will consider our position in due course and make an announcement when it suits us.

SENATOR CROWLEY asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 12 December 1996:
(1) What estimate does the department have for the increased cost of child care as a result of the removal of operational subsidy for community based Childcare centres.
(2) What estimate does the department have for the increased cost of child care as a result of the 50 hours per week restriction on child care assistance.
(3) What estimate does the department have for the increased cost of child care as a result of the removal of the child disallowance of the second child and subsequent children.
(4) What estimate does the department have for the increased cost of child care as a result of the reduce taper for income assessment for eligibility for child care assistance.
SENATOR NEWMAN—The Minister of Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:
(1) The level of cost increases will depend on services ability to achieve efficiencies in a competitive environment. Measures have been announced to help services restructure their operations.

(2) The decision to limit childcare assistance to 50 hours per week will not affect families who require more than 50 hours of care to meet their work‐related commitments (cares paid work, self employment, studying, looking for work and training. Travel time between the child care service and the place of work is also included.) Any fee increase experienced by families who are not using more than 50 hours of care but are being charged by their service for more than 50 hours will depend on the charging practice of their service.

(3) All families with one dependent child and all families currently in receipt of maximum Child Care Assistance—regardless of the number of children—will not be affected by this measure. Accordingly, approximately 80% of families will be unaffected. For those families that are affected, the impact of the decision will depend upon family income, number of dependents, number of children in care and hours of care paid for.

(4) All families with one dependent child and all families currently in receipt of maximum childcare assistance will not be affected by new annual income cut‐offs for families with 2 or more children. Due to indexation on 1 April 1997, families with two children in care will not be affected by this measure because the new income cut‐off will be higher than the current one. For those families that are affected the impact of the decision will depend upon family income, number of dependents, number of children in care and hours of care paid for.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present two reports of the committee entitled Development of facilities for the Army Logistics Training Centre and the Bandiana Logistics Group at Bandiana and Bonegilla, Victoria and 60th General Report 1996 . I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard and to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
The first report which I have tabled concerns the proposed development of the Army Logistics Training Centre and the Bandiana Logistics Group at Bandiana and Bonegilla, Victoria.
The proposal examined by the Committee involves the provision of office accommodation, trade training and structural facilities, weapons storage and repair and upgraded engineering services.
The estimated out‐turn cost of the proposed works is $16.081 million.
The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed.

The Army's facilities at Bandiana and Bonegilla have been developed over the past two decades. Facilities occupied by the Army Logistics Training Centre are a major investment for the training of soldiers. Activities range from initial trade and employment training to Non‐commissioned Officers and officer level courses. The types of courses offered include trade training, integrated logistics training, career and promotional training and equipment training.
The Committee concluded that there is a need to:
upgrade several administrative facilities for the Bandiana Logistics Group;
rationalise training facilities to support the creation of the Army Logistics Training Centre
rationalise messing in North Bandiana; and
further upgrade engineering services.

The scope of the proposed work examined by the Committee includes the adaptive reuse of seven existing buildings, the construction of extensions to four buildings and the construction of three new buildings.

The Committee concluded that the proposed development will rectify a number of deficiencies which have arisen as a result of organisational changes and can be justified because the Bandiana/Bonegilla area will remain as the Army's major logistics training establishment.

A number of organisations representing community interests strongly support the proposal. All pointed to the Army having been a long standing and significant part of the Albury/Wodonga community and an exemplary corporate citizen. In addition, the Army has integrated well within the regional community, and has contributed to regional income, employment, skills and infrastructure.

The Second report which I have tabled is the Committee's Sixtieth General report. This is for the last calendar year, but it must be remembered that members of the Committee were appointed in May and the first reference was not received until June.
The Committee received ten references during 1996 and reported on five of these. The remaining five references have either been reported on or will be reported on shortly.
The cost of projects reported on during the year was $88.526 million.
The year in review was marked by general agreement on public works proposals from organisations and individuals consulted by departments.

The Committee believes this is due to departments being more conscious of their obligations to consult early and widely during the development of proposals, before they are referred to the Committee.One positive result has been that public hearings have not been unduly protracted. Another result has been the avoidance of extraneous debate on issues of marginal relevance being introduced into the Committee's deliberations.
The Committee recognises that public works projects often result in benefits flowing to local communities, in addition to the actual buildings and services provided.

This was illustrated in two of the Committee's investigations during 1996. As part of the development of facilities in Townsville for the 5 Aviation Regiment and for infrastructure on the Townsville Field Training Area, the Townsville City Council commissioned a study by the Centre for Applied Economic Research at James Cook University, illustrating the economic benefits of each proposal.

The study showed that economic benefits flowing from the two Townsville projects amounted to a total of $120 million. The projects were also each predicted to create over 300 full‐time and part‐time jobs for members of the local community.

The fifth conference of Commonwealth and State Public Works Committees was hosted by a committee of the ACT Legislative Assembly on 5‐6 August 1996, in Canberra. Representatives of the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Queensland, South Australian, Tasmanian, ACT and New Zealand legislatures were in attendance. The conference provides a forum for discussion on the operations of public works committees across Australia and New Zealand and compares methods of scrutiny of funding for public works.

Under the Public Works Committee Act 1969, all public works estimated to cost $6 million or more must be referred to the Committee. Medium works—those with an estimated cost of between $2 million—$6 million may also be referred. The Committee is aware that some departments may divide a single project, costing more than $6 million, into two or more components to avoid the need for referral to the Committee. To avoid this, the Committee requests information from departments on medium works. The plans and sites may be inspected by the Committee, to determine if further investigation is warranted.

The Committee did not examine any new overseas works during the year. However, it did agree to a request from the Overseas Property Group to increase funding for the refurbishment of Australia House in London from $14.25 million to $21.28 million.
Consultations are continuing with appropriate Ministers to improve the Committee's effectiveness by enabling Committee Members to undertake on site inspections of overseas properties.
During the year, the Committee discussed the merits of amending the Public Works Committee Act 1969, to reflect current construction prices and to improve the Committee's administrative arrangements.
Suggestions included:
increasing the statutory limit for referrals from $6 million to a figure reflecting the higher cost of construction;

requiring that the Committee be kept informed of all public works within a certain range and, if considered in the public interest, allowing the Committee to conduct formal examination of any such project;
inserting a clause in the Act to allow the Committee to give approval for concurrent documentation; and
requiring a central agency to prepare an annual consolidated list of public works proposals for a given financial year.
At the end of 1996, the Committee was continuing its consideration of these matters, especially amendments to the Act and consequential arrangements.

During 1996, the House of Representatives Committee Office, which administers the Committee Secretariat, was restructured. The result of the restructuring is the linking of the secretariat with that of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. Resources are shared and staff allocated according to each Committee's workload. So far, the reorganisation has not affected the operations of the Committee.
I commend the reports to the Senate.
